profileAlternative.headline: Software Engineering Instructor
profileAlternative.summary:
I'm using my decades of software engineering experience and knowledge about C++ to make other people better software engineers. I train experienced software engineers to be better programmers. I present at and help run technical conferences and local user groups.
I'm passionate about quality code and want to inspire others to achieve their best engineering work.
I'm excited about modern C++ and how we can exploit the latest hardware developments with standard, portable C++.

positions.title: Software Engineering Instructor
positions.description:
I work with companies to custom tailor material that meets the needs of their software engineering teams and present it on-site. I specialize in bringing teams up to speed with modern C++ and presenting advance topics in C++. Commonly requested topics include best practices, generic programming and best use of STL, and performance critical applications.
I am an Approved Outside Vender for Scott Meyers training material. http://www.aristeia.com/training.html
Contact me at jon@cpp.training for information about availability and rates.

given.text:
I had the pleasure of working with Jon on Search Infrastructure team at A9 for several years. Jon is an exceptional engineer -- very productive, pragmatic, with incredible degree of expertise in a diverse set of technologies. However, what made him particularly stand out was his phenomenal ability to transfer knowledge, be it technical or otherwise. Jon's out-of-this-world sense of humor combined with his superb charisma made him the soul of our lunch outings. Often, someone would float an interview problem or a puzzle they recently learned about. Jon's ability to solve these was truly legendary. Once, after spending more than an hour on a problem, I asked: "How hard is it?" The answer I got was: "It's hard -- it took Kalb almost 30 seconds to crack it"... Those around Jon, including me, felt very fortunate, and eagerly sought out every opportunity to learn from him. While I was sad to hear Jon transitioned from an engineering career to that of an educator, because it meant we will likely not work together again, I also rejoiced for the much larger audiences who will now be able to benefit from his teaching ability.

Jon has been invaluable at exposing my fellow developers and I the details of modern C++ programming. After personally taking two of Jon's classes I feel I have improved as a developer, but also have a better sense as to the current state of the art in software engineering.

Jon is a C++ programming guru. He is also one of the best programmers I have ever known and certainly the easiest to get along with. He mentored several interns at Microsoft and conducted a weekly seminar on C++ programming and the Macintosh that was simply excellent.

Jon is the rare engineer who is truly and fully engaged and passionate about programming. He is also the first person I go to when I need a smart and creative problem solver to help me work through professional and programming issues. I hope we have the chance to work together again in the future because working with Jon has always been both a fun and an enlightening experience.

Jon has a proven track record of repeatedly delivering features in a complex large-scale software project, meeting restrictive deadlines while dealing with punishing legacy code. He has an encyclopedic knowledge of C++ and has highly developed architectural skills. More than that, Jon has a passion for the art and science of software engineering. received.text:
I've been working with Robin since he served as a volunteer at C++Now in May of 2016. Most C++Now volunteers are thirsty for C++ knowledge, but Robin distinguished himself in that, in addition to technical knowledge, he was particularly conscientious about his assignments as a volunteer. He was ready, even eager, to learn how the conference was run and to take on more responsibilities leading to a transition from volunteer to staff.

Robin is currently the Speaker Liaison for both C++Now and CppCon, the oldest and largest C++ conferences in the world, respectively. At both conferences he has taken on a number of other duties, most related to the conferences' technical content. His primary role, that of Speaker Liaison, is both very important to the conference and very time consuming for the liaison.

In addition to sending out information updates to all conference speakers, Robin is responsible for responding to the scores of questions and requests that we get every year from speakers, many of whom have not spoken at a conference before and some of whom make wrong assumptions about how these conferences are run.

In order to answer these questions and intermediate between speakers and other conference staff, Robin needs to know a lot of detail about how the conferences are run and I'm impressed that he can have learned all of that for both conference in so short a time.

Like all the best software engineers, Robin is detail oriented and in addition he is extremely conscientious and reliable. It makes my job as conference chair so much easier when Robin volunteers to take something on, because I know that it will be done and done right.

I'm impressed with Robin not just because he is a team player, executing on the plans developed (with his consultation) by the conference manager, but also because he's shown what he can do on his own.

Robin recognized that there is a wealth of C++ videos available, but almost all are in English and, except for the auto-subtitling on YouTube (which is awful for tech videos), these videos have no subtitles and no translations.

He saw a need and went after it. He created and has led the C++ Video Access Project to recruit, train, and coordinate volunteers to provide captioning and translation of C++ Videos.

The C++ community owes a lot to Robin and I look forward to seeing how his leadership will continue to shape the community's future.

In addition to my day job developing the Amazon product search engine, I chair and manage a couple of technical conferences. It was in this capacity that Jordi contacted me on behalf of Biicode.

Biicode was interested in engaging with the C++ community to drive adoption. This undertaking was made more challenging by a budget that was small even for a tech startup.

But due to Jordi's creativity and persistence we found a very economical way to gain recognition and gratitude from attendees at my oldest conference.

I look forward to seeing what kind of impact he can make given real resources.
